Award.AwardTitle: SHINE: Investigating the Dynamics of Coronal Mass Ejections from the Sun using Advanced Image Processing and Stereoscopy Techniques
Award.AbstractNarration:
Coronal mass ejections (CMEs) represent the largest, most dynamic phenomena that originate from the Sun. CMEs are also the biggest drivers of geomagnetic storms here on Earth that can damage satellites or ground-based technology. Predicting how and when they might impact our planet requires knowledge of the physics governing their eruption and propagation through inter-planetary space. This project integrates elements of discovery, cutting-edge techniques and observations, and international collaboration to provide new insights on this topic of great economic and societal concern. Specifically, the project seeks to obtain new insight into the detailed structure and evolution of CMEs, using newly developed coronal image processing and stereoscopic techniques on multi-viewpoint observations of the solar corona that have only recently become available. The project will mostly be carried out by the co-investigator who is a postdoctoral fellow at University of Hawaii, under the mentor ship of the principal investigator, thereby promoting the research training of an early career scientist. International collaborators from United Kingdom and Ireland will also contribute to the project.

This project concerns the development of improved methods for determining the dynamics of CME motion, and quantifying the associated uncertainties, which are proving successful for revealing the true trends in CME kinematics with much higher confidence than previously possible. These techniques also show great promise for exploring possible CME deflection and asymmetric expansion as they propagate through space. Specifically, the project will apply the advanced image processing methods of the CORIMP CME detection process, which combined with the recently developed elliptical tie-pointing technique allow for a three-dimensional analysis of CME structure and evolution for multiple events. Briefly stated, CORIMP characterizes the structure of CMEs in individual images via a dynamic separation process and multi-scale edge-detection algorithm, to study the dynamics of their propagation and evolution through space. The recently developed elliptical tie-pointing technique for 3D reconstructions of CMEs, is now being extended for use on combined SOHO and STEREO coronagraph images, in order to characterize CME morphology throughout the STEREO mission lifetime. As the spacecrafts have continued to separate in their orbits, they now provide unique observations from the far-side of the Sun, while SOHO provides ongoing observations from its location at L1 near Earth. A specific goal of the project is to generate 3D reconstructions of all candidate CMEs observed across the 7+ years of the STEREO mission.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this project was to explore the dynamical evolution  and physical characteristics of coronal mass ejections, i.e. CMEs, as they propagate through the ambient corona and their interaction with the solar wind, and to enhance our understanding of CMEs in the context of solar physics and space weather.

To achieve this goal, two major activities were undertaken throughout the duration of this award. They consisted of the development of advanced image processing tools, and the acquisition of spectroscopic observations during total solar eclipses, as described below.

(1) The development of advanced image processing and stereoscopy techniques enhanced our understanding of CMEs in the context of solar physics and space weather. The methods developed enabled the automatic detection, characterization and analysis of CME structures as derived from coronagraph images such as from SOHO/LASCO and STEREO/SECCHI. These led to the inference of their resulting kinematics and morphologies. The main outcome was the production of an online catalog for all CME detections in the LASCO data since the year 2000; outputting CME onset time, speed, acceleration, position angle, angular width, kinematic plots, and event movies. An online catalog  of 15 years of LASCO data on CMEs was developed and is currently hosted on servers at the Institute for Astronomy, Hawaii, at the following url: http://alshamess.ifa.hawaii.edu/CORIMP. The data from the catalog can be used to achieve statistical studies to characterize CMEs, and to identify trends, if any, depending on their physical properties.

(2) Observations of the corona during total solar eclipses using the power of imaging spectroscopy, enabled the measurements of key physical properties of CMEs, untenable through any other platform at present. The main advantages of using an imaging spectrograph are: (1) The simultaneous acquisition of spectra from different ionization states of several elements, such as Fe, Mg, He, ...  (2) Measurements of the variation of the intensity of the emission lines from these different elements, which can be mapped in the corona out to several solar radii above the limb. (3) Measurements of Doppler shifts, if present, yield outflows along the line of sight perpendicular to the plane of the sky. The novel design of the multi-channel imaging spectrometer, enabled the acquisition of first of their kind spectra of the corona during the total solar eclipses of 2015 and 2017. They revealed the presence of coronal mass ejections with speeds ranging from 100 to 1500 km/s. Furthermore, they showed that the bulk of the CME was at the higher temperatures in the corona, of 2 MK. Most surprisingly, they revealed, for the first time, the presence of remnants of neutrals and low ionized elements, resulting from the ejection of prominence material, responsible for the triggering of the CMEs. These cool inclusions were found to be traveling in tandem with the hot CME filaments at the same speeds.
